properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of brief but intense snowfall are expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-29T06:59:55-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls tonight. A well organized snow squall originating from Lake Huron has reached the region and will gradually move southward. This squall is capable of producing quick accumulations of 2 to 5 cm per hour along with sudden reductions to near zero visibility in heavy snow. This band is expected to move out of the region late tonight. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-29T08:59:57-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snow squalls remain possible tonight. An intense snow squall from Lake Huron has now moved south of the area. Additional snow squalls from Georgian Bay will be possible tonight as winds shift to a northwesterly direction. Motorists are advised to prepare for adverse travel conditions should the snow squalls develop. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls possible tonight through Saturday. Conditions will remain favourable for snow squalls to develop off of Lake Huron tonight. Travel may become hazardous, and motorists are advised to consider changing their travel plans accordingly. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-29T17:24:29-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions continue to occur from widespread blowing snow and heavy snow in snow squalls. Travel remains dangerous and is strongly discouraged. Snowfall over 70 cm has been reported in spots. A further 20 to 40 cm is possible in some locales tonight. Strong winds will create dangerous snow drifts. Conditions should gradually improve by Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected Saturday. Snowfall accumulations of 5 cm and strong winds gusting near 80 km/h will lead to significantly reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow on Saturday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 15 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 80 km/h (tonight). Locations: Labrador Straits area. Time span: continuing until Saturday. Remarks: snow and strong winds will combine to give near zero visibility at times in blowing snow tonight. Winds will ease Saturday morning allowing the blowing snow to subside, but snow will continue to accumulate throughout the day. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snow will begin to fall early Saturday morning with total accumulations of 10 to 20 cm expected by late Saturday night. Strong winds gusting between 70 and 80 km/h are also forecast, which when combined with the falling snow will produce very poor visibilities in snow and blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve early Sunday morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls continue tonight into Saturday. A couple of well organized snow squalls southeast of Lake Huron will continue to move southward tonight. Widespread blowing snow with local whiteout conditions is occurring. Travel remains dangerous and is strongly discouraged. 10 to 30 cm of new snowfall is expected tonight. Conditions will gradually improve by Saturday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-29T14:59:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-29T03:21:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2837510175.2020
Area: London - Parkhill - Eastern Middlesex County, Woodstock - Tillsonburg - Oxford County, Brantford - County of Brant, Goderich - Bluewater - Southern Huron County, Stratford - Mitchell - Southern Perth County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of brief but intense snowfall are expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. Snow squalls expected early this evening. A well organized snow squall originating from Lake Huron has reached the northern portions of the region and will gradually move south. This squall is capable of producing quick accumulations of 2 to 5 cm in an hour along with sudden reductions to near zero visibility in heavy snow. This band is expected to move out of the region by this evening. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-29T05:56:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-28T23:26:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0715383630.2020
Area: City of Toronto, Guelph - Erin - Southern Wellington County, Kitchener - Cambridge - Region of Waterloo, Mississauga - Brampton, Halton Hills - Milton
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm continues. A Pacific storm will track across central BC tonight. Snow associated with the system will continue over the Lakes District this evening. Additional amounts of 10 cm can be expected for communities south and east of Burns Lake. Snow will taper off overnight as the storm departs. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-29T14:49:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-28T23:27:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2957724999.2020
Area: Lakes District
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Additional snowfall: 10 cm except near 30 cm south of Hare Bay. Locations: Northern Peninsula East. Time span: until late Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will persist through Saturday with the highest amounts and heaviest snowfall rates expected south of Hare Bay. Winds will be strong enough to cause blowing snow and poor visibilities over exposed areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-29T18:14:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-29T02:15:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0365110110.2020
Area: Northern Peninsula East
properties.Author: Environment Canada
